markdownRemark.html:
Representing Elements and Sets

  • An element is an object
  • Specifically, an element can be an individual number, word, set, etc.
  • For example, {3,4}\text{\textbraceleft}{3, 4}\text{\textbraceright}{3,4} is an element of the set {1,2,{3,4}}\text{\textbraceleft}{1, 2, \text{\textbraceleft}{3, 4}\text{\textbraceright}}\text{\textbraceright}{1,2,{3,4}}
  • For example, {a,b}\text{\textbraceleft}{a, b}\text{\textbraceright}{a,b} is an element of the set {{a,b},c}\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{\textbraceleft}{a, b}\text{\textbraceright}, c}\text{\textbraceright}{{a,b},c}
  • A set is made up of elements
  • Since an element can be a set, then a set can contain other sets as well
  • For example, A\text{A}A is a valid set if A={1,2,3}\text{A} = \text{\textbraceleft}{1,2,3}\text{\textbraceright}A={1,2,3}, since 111, 222, and 333 are all valid elements of a set
  • Also, B\text{B}B is a valid set if B={1,2,{3,4}}\text{B} = \text{\textbraceleft}{1,2,\text{\textbraceleft}{3,4}\text{\textbraceright}}\text{\textbraceright}B={1,2,{3,4}}, since 111, 222, and {3,4}\text{\textbraceleft}{3, 4}\text{\textbraceright}{3,4} are all valid elements of a set
  • Also, C\text{C}C is a valid set if C={red,blue,green}\text{C} = \text{\textbraceleft}{red,blue,green}\text{\textbraceright}C={red,blue,green}, since the colors redredred, blueblueblue, and greengreengreen are all valid elements of a set

Set Notation

  • A set is a unique sequence of observable outcomes
  • For example, {1,2,3,4,5,6}\text{\textbraceleft}{1,2,3,4,5,6}\text{\textbraceright}{1,2,3,4,5,6} could be a set, representing the outcomes of rolling a single die
  • An event is a set of outcomes that is written as a capital letter
  • For example, we could denote a set that represents the outcomes of rolling a single die as the following:
A={1,2,3,4,5,6}\text{A} = \text{\textbraceleft}{1,2,3,4,5,6}\text{\textbraceright}A={1,2,3,4,5,6}
  • Keep in mind that events are written as a normal, capital letter, whereas a random variable is written as an italicized, capital letter
  • A realization of a random variable is written as a italicized, lower-case letter

Denoting Random Variables

  • As a reminder, a random variable is a function that maps a single value from a sample space to any single, real-number realization
  • Typically, we denote a random variable as the following:
X:Ω→RX: \Omega \to \RX:Ω→R such that ω↦X(ω)\text{such } \text{that } \omega \mapsto X(\omega)such that ω↦X(ω) such that ω∈Ω\text{such } \text{that } \omega \in \Omegasuch that ω∈Ω such that X(ω)∈R\text{such } \text{that } X(\omega) \in \Rsuch that X(ω)∈R
  • Here, Ω\OmegaΩ is a set that represents the domain of the random variable function
  • R\RR is a set that represents the range of the random variable function
  • ω\omegaω represents an element, or a single value, from the set Ω\OmegaΩ
  • X(ω)X(\omega)X(ω) represents an element, or a single value, from the set R\RR
  • X(ω)X(\omega)X(ω) also represents a realization of the random variable function

Denoting Probability

  • As a reminder, probability represent a function that maps a single value from the sample space to a realization that is in the interval of 0 and 1
  • Typically, the output of the random variable function becomes the input of the probability function
  • Therefore, the sample space will represent the range of the random variable
  • We denote a probability as the following:
P:Ω→[0,1]P: \Omega \to [0,1]P:Ω→[0,1] such that ω↦P(ω)\text{such } \text{that } \omega \mapsto P(\omega)such that ω↦P(ω)

Denoting Events

  • Sometimes, we don't want our function to map a single value from Ω\OmegaΩ, or we don't want our function to map to R\RR
  • In this situation, we would create an event

  • For example, we could have the following:

    • Let Ω\OmegaΩ denote the sample space
    • Let A\text{A}A be an event that is a subset of R\RR
    • Let XXX be our random variable
  • We could then define our random variable as the following:
X:Ω→AX: \Omega \to \text{A}X:Ω→A such that ω↦X(ω)\text{such } \text{that } \omega \mapsto X(\omega)such that ω↦X(ω) such that A⊂R\text{such } \text{that } \text{A} \subset \Rsuch that A⊂R such that ω∈Ω\text{such } \text{that } \omega \in \Omegasuch that ω∈Ω such that X(ω)∈A\text{such } \text{that } X(\omega) \in \text{A}such that X(ω)∈A
  • Here, Ω\OmegaΩ is a set that represents the domain of the random variable function
  • The set A\text{A}A is a set that represents the range of the random variable function
  • Also, A\text{A}A is an event that is a subset of all real numbers
  • ω\omegaω represents an element, or a single value, from the set Ω\OmegaΩ
  • X(ω)X(\omega)X(ω) represents an element, or a single value, from the event A\text{A}A

Another Example of Denoting Events

  • Let's say we have the following situation:

    • An event A\text{A}A is a subset of Ω\OmegaΩ
    • R\RR is a set of all real numbers
    • XXX is our random variable
  • We could define our random variable as the following:
X:A→RX: \text{A} \to \RX:A→R such that ω↦X(ω)\text{such } \text{that } \omega \mapsto X(\omega)such that ω↦X(ω) such that A⊂Ω\text{such } \text{that } \text{A} \subset \Omegasuch that A⊂Ω such that ω∈A\text{such } \text{that } \omega \in \text{A}such that ω∈A such that X(ω)∈R\text{such } \text{that } X(\omega) \in \Rsuch that X(ω)∈R
  • Here, the event A\text{A}A is a set that represents the domain of the random variable function
  • R\RR is a set that represents the range of the random variable function
  • Also, A\text{A}A is an event that is a subset of the sample space
  • ω\omegaω represents an element, or a single value, from the set A\text{A}A
  • X(ω)X(\omega)X(ω) represents an element, or a single value, from the set R\RR

One Last Example of Denoting Events

  • Let's say the following is true:

    • Let A\text{A}A be an event that represents the set {red, white, blue}
    • Let B\text{B}B be an event that represents the set {cat, dog}
    • Let XXX be our random variable
    • Let Ω\OmegaΩ be our sample space, which is the set of all colors
  • We could define our random variable as the following:
X:A→BX: \text{A} \to \text{B}X:A→B such that ω↦X(ω)\text{such } \text{that } \omega \mapsto X(\omega)such that ω↦X(ω) such that A={red,white,blue}\text{such } \text{that } \text{A} = \text{\textbraceleft}{red, white, blue}\text{\textbraceright}such that A={red,white,blue} such that B={cat,dog}\text{such } \text{that } \text{B} = \text{\textbraceleft}{cat, dog}\text{\textbraceright}such that B={cat,dog} such that ω∈A\text{such } \text{that } \omega \in \text{A}such that ω∈A such that X(ω)∈B\text{such } \text{that } X(\omega) \in \text{B}such that X(ω)∈B
  • Here, the event A\text{A}A is a set that represents the domain of the random variable function
  • Also, the event B\text{B}B is a set that represents the range of the random variable function
  • The set A\text{A}A is an event that is a subset of our sample space (i.e. colors)
  • The set B\text{B}B is an event that is a subset of animals
  • ω\omegaω represents an element, or a single value, from the event A\text{A}A
  • X(ω)X(\omega)X(ω) represents an element, or a single value, from the event B\text{B}B

Remarks on Mathematical Notation

  • As stated previously, a random variable XXX is a function defined as the following:
X:Ω→RX: \Omega \to \RX:Ω→R
  • However, we often refer to XXX using the following shorthand formula:
X(ω) such that ω∈ΩX(\omega) \text{ such} \text{ that } \omega \in \OmegaX(ω) such that ω∈Ω
  • Probability functions can be written in many ways:
pX(x)≡P(X=x)≡P({s∈S:X(s)=x})p_{X}(x) \equiv P(X = x) \equiv P(\text{\textbraceleft}{s \in S : X(s) = x}\text{\textbraceright})pX​(x)≡P(X=x)≡P({s∈S:X(s)=x})
  • We can generally denote sets as the following:
S≡{type of each element in list:range of each element}S \equiv \text{\textbraceleft}{\text{type of each element in list} : \text{range of each element}}\text{\textbraceright}S≡{type of each element in list:range of each element}
  • Here are a few examples showing how we can denote different sets:
S≡{i∈R:1≤i≤6,x is odd}S \equiv \text{\textbraceleft}{i \in \R : 1 \le i \le 6, x \text{ is odd}}\text{\textbraceright}S≡{i∈R:1≤i≤6,x is odd} S≡{(i,j):1≤i≤6,1≤j≤6}S \equiv \text{\textbraceleft}{(i, j) : 1 \le i \le 6, 1 \le j \le 6}\text{\textbraceright}S≡{(i,j):1≤i≤6,1≤j≤6}
  • We can also denote realizations as the following:
X(s)≡X((i,j))=i+jX(s) \equiv X((i, j)) = i + jX(s)≡X((i,j))=i+j

Further Notation

  • We can define sets as long as they obey either of the following notations:
{an element}∈{a set}\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{an element}}\text{\textbraceright} \in \text{\textbraceleft}{\text{a set}}\text{\textbraceright}{an element}∈{a set} {a set}∈{a collection of sets}\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{a set}}\text{\textbraceright} \in \text{\textbraceleft}{\text{a collection of sets}}\text{\textbraceright}{a set}∈{a collection of sets} {a set}⊂{a set}\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{a set}}\text{\textbraceright} \subset \text{\textbraceleft}{\text{a set}}\text{\textbraceright}{a set}⊂{a set} {a collection of sets}⊂{a collection of sets}\text{\textbraceleft}{\text{a collection of sets}}\text{\textbraceright} \subset \text{\textbraceleft}{\text{a collection of sets}}\text{\textbraceright}{a collection of sets}⊂{a collection of sets}

  • For example, we can write a∈Aa \in \text{A}a∈A

    • Where A\text{A}A is an event (which is a set)
    • Where aaa is an outcome or realization of A\text{A}A

  • We can also write A∈ℑ\text{A} \in ℑA∈ℑ

    • Where A\text{A}A is an event (which is a set)
    • Where ℑℑℑ is an algebra (which is a collection of sets)

  • Or, we can write A⊂B\text{A} \subset \text{B}A⊂B

    • Where A\text{A}A and B\text{B}B are both events (which are sets)

  • We can also write ℑ0⊂ℑ1ℑ_{0} \subset ℑ_{1}ℑ0​⊂ℑ1​

    • Where ℑ0ℑ_{0}ℑ0​ is an algebra (which is a collection of sets) that is contained within an algebra ℑ1ℑ_{1}ℑ1​ (which is larger a collection of sets)
